tit.e: Engishiki Jinmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan)
Engishiki Jinmyocho (register of shrines in Japan)
tit.cmt: As this is a title, I don't think the article is necessary.
tit.e: Engishiki Jinmyocho (register of shrines in Japan)

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳（えんぎしき じんみょうちょう）とは、延長 (日本)5年（927年）にまとめられた『延喜式』の巻九・十のことで、当時「官社」とされていた全国の神社一覧である。
sen.e: The Engishiki Jinmyocho is the ninth and the tenth volumes of the "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), which was documented in 927, and this is a list of the shrines labeled as 'kansha' (official shrines) throughout the country at that time.

The Engishiki Jinmyocho is the name given to the ninth and the tenth volumes of the "Engishiki" (an ancient Japanese book of administrative regulations and ceremonial procedures that was completed in 927), which provide a list of shrines throughout the country that were designated as 'kansha' (official shrines) at that time.
sen.cmt: This looks like a lot has been rewritten but the meaning was pretty clear and I've just tidied it up really.
sen.e: The Engishiki Jinmyocho is the name given to the ninth and the tenth volumes of the "Engishiki" (an ancient Japanese book of administrative regulations and ceremonial procedures that was completed in 927), which provide a list of shrines throughout the country that were designated as 'kansha' (official shrines) at that time.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳に記載された神社を、「延喜式の内に記載された神社」の意味で延喜式内社、または単に式内社（しきないしゃ）、式社（しきしゃ）といい、一種の社格となっている。
sen.e: The shrines listed on the Engishiki Jinmyocho are called Engishikinaisha, or simply Shikinaisha or Shikisha, meaning 'shrines listed in the Engishiki,' and these terms also represent a shrine ranking.

The shrines listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho are called Engishikinaisha (or simply Shikinaisha or Shikisha), meaning 'shrines listed in the Engishiki,' and this term also represents a kind of shrine ranking.

The shrines listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho are called Engishikinaisha (or simply Shikinaisha or Shikisha), meaning 'shrines listed in the Engishiki,' and this term also represents a kind of shrine ranking.

sen.j: 元々「神名帳」とは、古代律令制における神祇官が作成していた官社の一覧表のことで、官社帳ともいう。
sen.e: Jinmyocho' is originally a kansha list created by Jingikan (the department of worship), which was instituted in the kodai ritsuryosei (the ancient East Asian system of centralized governance), and is also called Kanshacho (a book of official shrines).
sen.cmt: 文頭のアポストロフィは単独ですと文字列記号として認識されてしまいセル上で表示されませんので、二重でつけてあります。
sen.e: The 'Jinmyocho' was originally a kansha list created by the Jingikan (department of worship), which was instituted under the kodai ritsuryosei (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes that was introduced in ancient Japan), and it is also called the Kanshacho (book of official shrines).
sen.cmt: It's great that the translator has taken the time to provide explanations for terms that the reader would otherwise have trouble understanding. In this case, however, I'm not sure that the ritsuryosei can be described as the "ancient East Asian system of centralized governance" as, although it was based on the Chinese system, I don't think this particular system was introduced in any other Asian countries was it?
sen.e: The 'Jinmyocho' was originally a kansha list created by the Jingikan (department of worship), which was instituted under the kodai ritsuryosei (ancient East Asian system of centralized governance), and it is also called the Kanshacho (book of official shrines).
sen.cmt: NCのコメントを読み、用語集にある古代律令制の説明に変更しました。

sen.j: 国・郡別に神社が羅列されており、祭神、社格などが記されている。
sen.e: The shrines are sorted according to their provinces and districts, along with their respective enshrined deities and shrine rankings.
The shrines are sorted according to their provinces and districts, along with their respective enshrined deities and shrine rankings.
The shrines are sorted according to their provinces and districts, along with their respective enshrined deities and shrine rankings.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳とは、延喜式がまとめられた当時の神名帳を掲載したものである。
sen.e: The Engishiki Jinmyocho is the series of the Jinmyocho as of the time that the Engishiki was documented.
The Engishiki Jinmyocho is the series of the Jinmyocho as of the time that the Engishiki was documented.
The Engishiki Jinmyocho is the series of the Jinmyocho as of the time that the Engishiki was documented.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳に記載された神社（式内社）は全国で2861社であり、そこに鎮座する神 (神道)の数は3132座である。
sen.e: The Engishiki Jinmyocho lists 2861 shrines (thus called Shikinaisha) across the country, and the number of their enshrined deities (Shinto) is 3132.
The Engishiki Jinmyocho lists 2861 shrines (thus called Shikinaisha) across the country, and the number of their enshrined deities (Shinto) is 3132.
The Engishiki Jinmyocho lists 2861 shrines (thus called Shikinaisha) across the country, and the number of their enshrined deities (Shinto) is 3132.

sen.j: 式内社は、延喜式がまとめられた10世紀初頭には朝廷から官社として認識されていた神社であり、その選定には政治色が強く反映されている。
sen.e: The Shikinaisha shrines were regarded as official shrines by the Imperial Court at the beginning of the tenth century when the Engishiki was edited, and its selection is greatly affected by the political situation.

The Shikinaisha shrines were regarded as official shrines by the Imperial Court at the beginning of the tenth century when the Engishiki was edited, and its selection was greatly affected by the political situation.

The Shikinaisha shrines were regarded as official shrines by the Imperial Court at the beginning of the 10th century when the Engishiki was edited, and its selection was greatly affected by the political situation.

sen.j: 当時すでに存在したはずであるのに延喜式神名帳に記載されていない神社を式外社（しきげしゃ）という。
sen.e: Shrines which definitely existed at that time but were not listed on the Engishiki Jinmyocho are called Shikigesha.
Shrines which definitely existed at that time but were not listed on the Engishiki Jinmyocho are called Shikigesha.
Shrines which definitely existed at that time but were not listed on the Engishiki Jinmyocho are called Shikigesha.

sen.j: 式外社には、朝廷の勢力範囲外の神社や、独自の勢力を持っていた神社（熊野那智大社など）、また、神仏習合により仏を祀る寺であると認識されていた神社、僧が管理をしていた神社（石清水八幡宮など）、正式な社殿を有していなかった神社などが含まれる。
sen.e: The Shikigesha shrines include shrines which were out of the Imperial Court's sphere, shrines which had their own influence (such as Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrine), shrines which were thought to enshrine the Buddha due to the syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism, shrines which were under Buddhist priests' control (such as Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine), and shrines which did not have a formal shrine building.

The Shikigesha shrines include shrines which were out of the Imperial Court's sphere, shrines which had their own influence (such as Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrine), shrines which were thought to enshrine the Buddha due to the syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism, shrines which were under Buddhist priests' control (such as Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine), and shrines which did not have a formal shrine building.

The Shikigesha shrines include shrines which were out of the Imperial Court's sphere, shrines which had their own influence (such as Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrine), shrines which were thought to enshrine the Buddha due to the syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism, shrines which were under Buddhist priests' control (such as Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine), and shrines which did not have a formal shrine building.

sen.j: 式外社であるが六国史にその名前が見られる神社のことを特に国史現在社（国史見在社とも）と呼ぶ（広義には式内社であるものも含む）。
sen.e: The Shikigesha shrines which are listed on the Rikkokushi (Japan's six national histories) are specially referred to as Kokushigenzaisha (some Shikinaisha shrines are also included in this in a broad sense).
sen.cmt: 国史見在社の読みは国史現在社と同じであり、漢字表記の違いのみであるため、英文では訳出しておりません。
sen.e: The Shikigesha shrines which are listed on the Rikkokushi (Japan's six national histories) are specially referred to as Kokushigenzaisha (some Shikinaisha shrines are also included in this in a broad sense).

The Shikigesha shrines which are listed on the Rikkokushi (Japan's six national histories) are specially referred to as Kokushigenzaisha (some Shikinaisha shrines are also included in this in a broad sense).

sen.j: 式内社の社格
sen.e: The rankings of the Shikinaisha shrines
The rankings of the Shikinaisha shrines
The rankings of the Shikinaisha shrines

sen.j: 式内社は各種の種別がある。
sen.e: There are several classifications of the Shikinaisha shrines.
There are several classifications of the Shikinaisha shrines.
There are several classifications of the Shikinaisha shrines.

sen.j: まず官幣社と国幣社の別である。
sen.e: Firstly, they are classified into Kanpeisha (shrines designated as official by Jingikan) and Kokuheisha (shrines under the control of provincial governors).
Firstly, they are classified into Kanpeisha (shrines designated as official by Jingikan) and Kokuheisha (shrines under the control of provincial governors).
Firstly, they are classified into Kanpeisha (shrines designated as official by Jingikan) and Kokuheisha (shrines under the control of provincial governors).

sen.j: 官社とは、毎年2月の祈年祭に神祇官から幣帛を受ける神社のことであり、各神社の祝部が神祇官に集まって幣帛を受け取っていた。
sen.e: The kansha shrines are the shrines which receive heihaku (Shinto offering such as cloth, paper, and rope) from Jingikan at the Kinen-sai festival (a prayer service for a good crop) held in February of each year, and hafuribe (local priests) from each shrine gathered at Jingikan to receive heihaku.

The kansha shrines are the shrines which receive heihaku (Shinto offering such as cloth, paper, and rope) from Jingikan at the Kinen-sai festival (a prayer service for a good crop) held in February of each year, and hafuribe (local priests) from each shrine gathered at Jingikan to receive heihaku.

The kansha shrines are the shrines which receive heihaku (Shinto offering such as cloth, paper, and rope) from Jingikan at the Kinen-sai festival (a prayer service for a good crop) held in February of each year, and hafuribe (local priests) from each shrine gathered at Jingikan to receive heihaku.

sen.j: これが、延暦17年（798年）、それまで通り神祇官から幣帛を受ける官幣社と、その令制国の国司から幣帛を受ける国幣社とに分けられた。
sen.e: In 798, the kansha shrines were divided into Kanpeisha which continued to receive heihaku from Jingikan, and Kokuheisha which received heihaku from a kokushi (provincial governor) of the ryoseikoku (province) in where that shrine was.

In 798, the kansha shrines were divided into Kanpeisha which continued to receive heihaku from Jingikan, and Kokuheisha which received heihaku from a kokushi (provincial governor) of the ryoseikoku (province) in where that shrine was.

In 798, the kansha shrines were divided into Kanpeisha which continued to receive heihaku from Jingikan, and Kokuheisha which received heihaku from a kokushi (provincial governor) of the ryoseikoku (province) in where that shrine was.

sen.j: 式内社では、官幣社が573社737座、国幣社が2288社2395座である。
sen.e: Shikinaisha consists of 573 Kanpeisha shrines with 737 enshrined deities and 2288 Kokuheisha shrines with 2395 enshrined deities.
Shikinaisha consists of 573 Kanpeisha shrines with 737 enshrined deities and 2288 Kokuheisha shrines with 2395 enshrined deities.
Shikinaisha consists of 573 Kanpeisha shrines with 737 enshrined deities and 2288 Kokuheisha shrines with 2395 enshrined deities.

sen.j: 国幣社が設けられたのは、遠隔地の神社では祝部の上京が困難であるためとされているが、遠隔地でも重要な神社は官幣社とされている。
sen.e: Although it is believed that Kokuheisha was set up because hafuribe at shrines in distant provinces had difficulty in traveling to the capital city, some significant shrines in distant provinces were classified as Kanpeisha.

Although it is believed that Kokuheisha was set up because hafuribe at shrines in distant provinces had difficulty in traveling to the capital city, some significant shrines in distant provinces were classified as Kanpeisha.

Although it is believed that Kokuheisha was set up because hafuribe at shrines in distant provinces had difficulty in traveling to the capital city, some significant shrines in distant provinces were classified as Kanpeisha.

sen.j: 次が大社と小社の別である。
sen.e: Secondly, the Shikinaisha shrines are classified into Taisha (grand shrines) and Shosha (minor shrines).
Secondly, the Shikinaisha shrines are classified into Taisha (grand shrines) and Shosha (minor shrines).
Secondly, the Shikinaisha shrines are classified into Taisha (grand shrines) and Shosha (minor shrines).

sen.j: この別はその神社の重要度や社勢によって定められたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is believed that the shrines were classified according to their significance and influence.
It is believed that the shrines were classified according to their significance and influence.
It is believed that the shrines were classified according to their significance and influence.

sen.j: 官幣社・国幣社および大社・小社は全ての式内社について定められているので、式内社は以下の4つのいずれかに分類されることになる。
sen.e: Since every Shikinaisha shrine has to be classified into Kanpeisha or Kokuheisha, and Taisha or Shosha, each Shikinaisha shrine must belong to one of the following four groups.
Since every Shikinaisha shrine has to be classified into Kanpeisha or Kokuheisha, and Taisha or Shosha, each Shikinaisha shrine must belong to one of the following four groups.
Since every Shikinaisha shrine has to be classified into Kanpeisha or Kokuheisha, and Taisha or Shosha, each Shikinaisha shrine must belong to one of the following four groups.

sen.j: 官幣大社
sen.e: Kanpei-taisha (grand shrines under the control of the department of worship)

sen.j: 官幣大社は畿内に集中しているが、その他の地方にも分布している。
sen.e: Most Kanpei-taisha shrines are in the vicinal territories of the capital, but some are in other regions as well.
Most Kanpei-taisha shrines are in the vicinal territories of the capital, but some are in other regions as well.
Most Kanpei-taisha shrines are in the vicinal territories of the capital, but some are in other regions as well.

sen.j: 官幣小社は全て畿内に、国幣大社・国幣小社は全て畿外にある。
sen.e: All the Kanpei-shosha shrines are in the vicinal territories of the capital, and all the Kokuhei-taisha and Kokuhei-shosha shrines are out of the vicinal territories of the capital.
All the Kanpei-shosha shrines are in the vicinal territories of the capital, and all the Kokuhei-taisha and Kokuhei-shosha shrines are out of the vicinal territories of the capital.
All the Kanpei-shosha shrines are in the vicinal territories of the capital, and all the Kokuhei-taisha and Kokuhei-shosha shrines are out of the vicinal territories of the capital.

sen.j: なお、近代社格制度にも同じ名称の社格があるが、式内社の社格とはその示す意味が異なる。
sen.e: Although the modern shrine ranking system has some rankings named the same, such rankings refer to different types of classification from the Shikinaisha rankings.
Although the modern shrine ranking system has some rankings named the same, such rankings refer to different types of classification from the Shikinaisha rankings.
Although the modern shrine ranking system has some rankings named the same, such rankings refer to different types of classification from the Shikinaisha rankings.

sen.j: また、近代社格制度の社格は延喜式における社格とは関係なく、制定時の重要度や社勢に応じて定められている。
sen.e: Also, the shrine rankings in the modern system have nothing to do with the shrine rankings in the Engishiki, and they are classified according to their importance and influence as of the modern system's establishment.

Also, the shrine rankings in the modern system have nothing to do with the shrine rankings in the Engishiki, and they are classified according to their importance and influence towards the modern system's establishment.

Also, the shrine rankings in the modern system have nothing to do with the shrine rankings in the Engishiki, as they are determined according to the importance and influence of the shrines at the time of ranking.
sen.cmt: towards だと原文の意味が変わってくると思われるので変更しました。

sen.j: 式内社の中には、祈年祭以外の祭にも幣帛に預かる神社があり、社格とともに記されている。
sen.e: Shikinaisha includes some shrines that receive heihaku at some services other than the Kinen-sai festival, and such shrines have a note about this along with their shrine rankings.
Shikinaisha includes some shrines that receive heihaku at some services other than the Kinen-sai festival, and such shrines have a note about this along with their shrine rankings.
Shikinaisha includes some shrines that receive heihaku at some services other than the Kinen-sai festival, and such shrines have a note about this along with their shrine rankings.

sen.j: 名神
sen.e: Myojin
Myojin
Myojin

sen.j: -- 特に霊験著しい「名神」を祀る、臨時祭の名神祭が行われる神社。
sen.e: There are some shrines that enshrine 'Myojin', the wonder-working deities, and have an extraordinary festival called the Myojin-sai festival.
There are some shrines that enshrine 'Myojin', the wonder-working deities, and have an extraordinary festival called the Myojin-sai festival.
There are some shrines that enshrine 'Myojin', the wonder-working deities, and have an extraordinary festival called the Myojin-sai festival.

sen.j: 全てが大社であることから名神大社（名神大）という
sen.e: These shrines are called Myojin-taisha (or Myojindai) because they are all classified into Taisha.
These shrines are called Myojin-taisha (or Myojindai) because they are all classified into Taisha.
These shrines are called Myojin-taisha (or Myojindai) because they are all classified into Taisha.

sen.j: 月次
sen.e: Tsukinami
Tsukinami

sen.j: -- 月次祭（6月と12月の年2回行われる祭）に幣帛を受ける神社
sen.e: The shrines that receive heihaku at the Tsukinami-sai festival (the festival held half-yearly, in June and December)
The shrines that receive heihaku at the Tsukinami-sai festival (the festival held half-yearly, in June and December)

sen.j: 相嘗
sen.e: Ainame
Ainame

sen.j: -- 相嘗祭（新嘗祭に先立ち新穀を供える祭）が行われる神社
sen.e: The shrines that have the Ainame-sai festival (a prayer to offer new crops to the deities before the Niiname-sai festival)
The shrines that have the Ainame-sai festival (a prayer to offer new crops to the deities before the Niiname-sai festival)

sen.j: 新嘗
sen.e: Niiname
Niiname

sen.j: -- 新嘗祭（毎年11月に行われる一年の収穫を祝う祭）に幣帛を受ける神社
sen.e: The shrines that receive heihaku at The Niiname-sai festival (The festival held in November of each year to celebrate a harvest in that year)
The shrines that receive heihaku at The Niiname-sai festival (The festival held in November of each year to celebrate a harvest in that year)

sen.j: 論社
sen.e: Ronja (shrines considered to be descendants of Shikinaisha)
Ronja (shrines considered to be descendants of Shikinaisha)
Ronja (shrines considered to be descendants of Shikinaisha)

sen.j: 式内社の後裔が現在のどの神社であるのかを比定する研究は古くから行われている。
sen.e: There has been a study to specify the descendent shrines of the Shikinaisha shrines for a long time.
There has been a study to specify the descendents of the Shikinaisha shrines for a long time.
There has been a study to specify the descendents of the Shikinaisha shrines for a long time.

sen.j: 神社の社名や祭神、鎮座地が変更されていたり、他の神社に合祀されていたり、また、一度荒廃した後に復興されたりした場合、式内社の後裔と目される神社が複数になることがある。
sen.e: If a shrine's name, its enshrined deity, or its enshrinement place has been changed, the shrine has been merged with another shrine, and/or it has been reestablished after falling to ruin, it sometimes produces more than one shrine that are considered to be a Shikinaisha descendant.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If a shrine's name, its enshrined deity, or its enshrinement place has been changed, the shrine has been merged with another shrine, and/or it has been reestablished after falling to ruin, it sometimes produces more than one shrine that are considered to be a Shikinaisha descendant.

If a shrine's name, its enshrined deity, or its enshrinement place has been changed, the shrine has been merged with another shrine, and/or it has been reestablished after falling to ruin, it sometimes produces more than one shrine that are considered to be a Shikinaisha descendant.

sen.j: その場合それぞれの神社を論社という。
sen.e: In that case, each of such shrines are referred to as Ronja.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In that case, such shrines are referred to as Ronja.
In that case, such shrines are referred to as Ronja.

sen.j: 論社には、他者の研究によって後裔社だとされることもあるが、その神社自らが式内社であると主張する場合も多く見られる。
sen.e: The Ronja shrines include many shrines that they themselves insist they are Shikinaisha as well as some shrines which are acknowledged as a descendant shrine by external researchers.
The Ronja shrines include many shrines that they themselves insist are Shikinaisha as well as some shrines which are acknowledged to be a descendant shrine by external researchers.
The Ronja shrines include many shrines that they themselves insist are Shikinaisha as well as some shrines which are acknowledged to be a descendant shrine by external researchers.

sen.j: 近年、現存の式内社についての全国調査が行われており、その結果が『式内社調査報告』（式内社研究会 編、皇學館大学出版部）として刊行されている。
sen.e: In recent years, they have had a nationwide survey of the extant Shikinaisha shrines, and its result has been published in "Shikinaisha Chosa Hokoku." (The Report of the Shikinaisha Survey) (edited by Shikinaisha Kenkyukai, the Kogakkan University publishing department)
sen.cmt: 原文「近年」を「in recent years」と訳しましたが、実際に「式内社研究会」が発足したのは1974年、また「式内社調査報告」第1巻が出版されたのは1979年であるため、この原文および訳文よりイメージされる期間と実際の期間とに相違がある可能性がございます。
sen.e: In recent years, they have had a nationwide survey of the extant Shikinaisha shrines, and its result has been published in "Shikinaisha Chosa Hokoku." (The Report of the Shikinaisha Survey) (edited by Shikinaisha Kenkyukai, the Kogakkan University publishing department)

In recent years, they have had a nationwide survey of the extant Shikinaisha shrines, and its result has been published in "Shikinaisha Chosa Hokoku." (The Report of the Shikinaisha Survey) (edited by Shikinaisha Kenkyukai, the Kogakkan University publishing department)
